awd_titl_txt: Refining Understanding of the Home Math Environment in the Early Years: An Interdisciplinary Working Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
This award to Purdue University provides partial support for a conference focused on the home numeracy environment (HNE). The conference addresses this critically important topic, drawing on researchers from a range of disciplines and literatures. A robust finding across these literatures is that achievement gaps in math exist at preschool and largely persist through high school. Though it is clear that socio-economic status (SES) plays a significant role in producing these gaps, a better understanding of specific causal mechanisms is needed. Moreover, there may be other important home-based factors that could inoculate children, protecting them from lagging behind in mathematics upon school entry. The conference is a unique opportunity for researchers across disciplines to share the results of their cutting-edge work, receive feedback on the translational opportunities, and get a sense of how to move forward. The project is funded by the EHR Core Research program, which supports fundamental research that advances the research literature on STEM learning.

The conference has three aims: First, discussion around variability in HNE across age and culture; second, the development of a review of the extant literature on HNE (identifying gaps and future directions); and, third, the development of a better survey measure of HNE. The output of the conference will include a working paper that presents a coherent vision for the HNE research community. The award will largely help offset expenses for participants related to travel. It will also support the development of the position paper that provides a foundation for the field to move forward.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this project center around one core event (the virtual conference) and two core products (Next Directions article and Open Access HME dataset).

Virtual Conference: A virtual conference on Next Directions in the Measurement of the HME was held in fall 2020 across three 2 hour sessions, one asynchonous poster session, and five subsequent writing sessions. In total, 57 scholars from 14 different countries participated in the first three sessions, 189 unique visitors participated in the asynchonous poster session (there were 45 posters), and 39 of the original 57 scholars participated in the subsequent writing sessions. These sessions all led to substantial discussion and synthesis of the current state of the field and next directions for research.

Next Directions article: As a result of the writing sessions, an article (Next Directions in Measurement of the Home Mathematics Environment: An International and Interdisciplinary Perspective) was published in the Journal of Numerical Cognition that outlines key questions and core considerations for future work. The open access article can be found here: https://jnc.psychopen.eu/index.php/jnc/article/view/6143/6143.pdf

Open Access HME Dataset: As a result of the conference and subsequent discussions, a comprehensive listing of potential HME-related survey questions was compiled by the PI and collaborators. This list of questions covered the breadth of content areas discussed during the conference and synthesized across existing measures. New questions were also constructed. The research team then collected survey data from over 1,000 families using the online data collection platform Prolific. The data that were collected were then cleaned and deidentified, a code-book was created, and the dataset was posted in the online data respository LDBase. The dataset and codebook can be found here: https://www.ldbase.org/datasets/2d78d002-9e32-44b0-b8ca-8e0f2291bed9
